title-group.article-title: Comments on ‘Experimental versus computational analysis of micromotions at the implant - bone interface’

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratorio di Tecnologia Medica, Istituto Ortopedico Rizzoli, Italy
2Facoltá di Ingegneria, Universitá di Bologna, Italy
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Sheffield, UK

body.p: We read the paper by Tarala et al.,1 which was recently published in this Journal. We believe the authors addressed a very important issue. In fact, we agree that artifacts are induced by bone deformation when implant–bone micromotion is measured at points that are far from each other, and more, in general we agree on the importance of assessing the precision of experimental measurements (as well as of numerical simulations). We would like to comment on some points.

First of all, when quoting some of our previous studies2,3 they state ‘a single LVDT implant–bone relative motion measurement system is mounted transcortically by means of an anchorage set-up; the motion is measured between the pin connected to the stem and the linear variable differential transformers (LVDTs) support attached to the bone surface’. This is partly true for one of the two quoted papers3 (even in this paper three linear variable differential transformers (LVDTs) and one extensometer were used, not just ‘a single LVDT’). This statement is inaccurate for the other paper:2 in fact, as shown in that paper,2 the reference frame of each of the four LVDTs was connected to the bone close (500 micron) to the stem–bone interface (as opposed to the bone surface) by means of a tiny sleeve inserted onto the transcortical holes (Figure 1). We used the same type of fixation for the LVDTs in a number of later studies on cemented and cementless stems,4–14 many of which are published in this Journal, which Tarala et al.1 did not mention. Therefore, the statement that ‘None of these experimental methods allow for micromotion measurement at the actual implant–bone interface’ seems unjustified.

caption.p: Experimental setup used for measuring implant micromotions close to the cement-stem interface in cemented implants (a), or to the bone-stem interface in cementless implants (b). A hole (3.5 mm in diameter) is drilled across the cortical thickness. The LVDT is supported by a holder that is connected to a thin sleeve, which is inserted into such a transcortical hole. The changes in diameter of the sleeve allow fixing such a holder close (0.5 mm) to the stem surface, while there is a sub-millimeter clearance between the bone and the holder close to the bone surface. The moving core of the LVDT is connected to a thin transcortical pin having a spherical tip (1.0 mm in diameter), which is inserted into a 1-mm hole drilled in the stem surface. The contact between the tip of the probe and the stem is located 0.5 mm below the stem surface. Figure adapted from.2,4,5

body.p: Second, referring to the errors induced by elastic deformation of bone, Tarala et al.1 state ‘It is not possible to assess the magnitude of these errors with the currently available experimental methods’. This is incorrect. In fact, in a study that they quoted2 we measured experimentally the relative motion of different points across the thickness of cortical wall. The anchorage of the LVDTs was fixed to the external surface of the bone, while the pin attached to the LVDT probe sensed the shear motions corresponding to the elastic strains at three controlled depths across the cortex (500 micron below the external surface, 500 micron above the bone–stem interface, and midway between these two levels). The LVDTs we used had an intrinsic precision of 1 micron, and the entire measurement system had an overall precision of better than 2.3 micron.2 The relative motions between a point on the external bone surface and the point close (500 micron) to the stem–bone interface did not exceed 5 micron in any of the bone areas where such artifact was assessed. Furthermore, based on the micromotions measured at three depths, it can be seen that such relative motion varied, more or less linearly, across the thickness of the cortical wall. Similarly, in a latter study15 a different group investigated this type of error combining in vitro measurements with a validated FE model.

Third, Tarala et al.1 aim at assessing the error of experimental measurements. As a general rule, in order to measure the uncertainty of a measurement system it is necessary to use something that is more precise than the system under investigation.16 However, the precision of their finite element (FE) models is questionable:

list-item.p: The FE models were compared against experimental measurements (roentgen stereophotogrammetric analysis (RSA), with a reported precision of 40 micron) only for the overall deflection of the bone. Even under these conditions, validation was good for the CLS specimens, but an average error of 38% can be inferred for the EPOCH.
The precision of these FE models in predicting relative micromotions has not been reported by Tarala et al.1

body.p: In fact, the error Tarala et al.1 estimated for the micromotions measured when the transducer is fixed to the external bone surface (hundreds of microns) are two orders of magnitude higher than those we measured experimentally (less than 5 micron, with a precision of better than 2.3 micron2). While our measurement is based on calibrated transducers and a validated method of measuring relative micromotions,2 the same cannot be said for this specific application of the FE models of Tarala et al.1

It must be noted that the artifacts discussed by Tarala et al.1 are found when a loaded and unloaded state are compared, such as when measuring the elastic (inducible) micromotion. The consequences of elastic deformation across the cortical bone become negligible when two instants with the same load applied are compared, such as measuring permanent migration that is accumulated cycle after cycle.2,15

We agree with Tarala et al.1 that unwise choices in the design of these experiments might produce systematic errors of considerable entity. However, we are concerned that an inexperienced reader might draw the erroneous conclusion that all experimental results published in the literature are affected by such errors, and thus invalid. When experimental setups, such as those described in Monti et al.,2 Cristofolini et al.,4,12,13 are used, the measurements are extremely reliable and accurate, as it has been established in the cited papers where such accuracy has been quantified. With the necessary methodological attention, it is possible to accurately measure the bone–implant relative micromotion in vitro.
